Dame Evtice hire Moder moder het &punctelev; þat hire to wommane b&rrot;ouȝte
Of hire childe wel glad heo was &punctelev; a&slong;e heo &slong;u&ydot;þe wel ouȝte
So bifeol þat on Dame Eutice cam a &slong;ikne&slong;&slong;e &punctelev; &slong;wiþe greuou&slong; and long
Four ȝer he heo hadde gret pine &punctelev; þe meni&slong;on of blode wel &slong;trong
On leche&slong; heo hadde i&slong;pendet i&slong;pendedet &punctelev; Muche muche del of hire guod

Þat wa&slong; þe chaffare þe bli&slong;&slong;e of heuene &punctelev; þat heo hadde ibouȝt
gret wonder he hadde of þulke Answere answere &punctelev; and &slong;tod ⁁in gret þouȝt&slong;tod The caret and annotation are in a later hand. Thhe marginal annotation is not an insertion into the text but a clarification of the slightly ill-formed letter shapes in "stood". As such, it should probably not be represented with the add element.
So þat he onderȝat sone &punctelev; þat heo cri&slong;tine wa&slong;
In grete wrathþe he tolde fo&rrot;e &punctelev; þe Iu&slong;tice iustice þat het þakas Pakas
Lucie wa&slong; &slong;one ifet &punctelev; and bifo&rrot;e þe Iu&slong;tice iustice ib&rrot;ouȝt
Maide &slong;eide þe Iu&slong;tice iustice &punctelev; ȝwat ha&slong;t þou ibrouȝtþouȝt The erasure of the "ibr" (clearly a duplication of the previous line) is apparently original but no further change was made to the text. A latter hand interprets the intended word as "þouȝt", whereas Horstmann thought it was "iþouȝt".
¶Let þi folie he &slong;eide &punctelev; Ich rede on alle wi&slong;&slong;eHorstmann reads "wiffe", but this may well be a printer's error from his handwritten notes.
And to o&rrot;e gode&slong; a&slong;e riȝt is &punctelev; do þine &slong;acreficeThe "c" at the end of "sacrefice" may well be corrected to an "s", as Horstmann seems to have thought.

And þerto ichulle mi bodi take &punctelev; ȝwane me ni&slong; bileued nomo&rrot;e

And euerech lime In in is serui&slong;e &punctelev; nov me ni&slong; mo&rrot;e bileued

to spened ech lime In in is &slong;erui&slong;e &punctelev; do ȝwat þou wolt bi meThe correction in "spend" looks very much like it was done by the later hand found elsewhere on the page.

¶And þare &slong;chal mani a moderchild &punctelev; go to þi foule licame·/ At this point the scribe begins writing the text as prose. A solidus written by a later hand marks the division. The same hand has inserted the solidus elsewhere in an attempt to identify poetic line breaks in the middle of the manuscript lines.

¶ Ne mai no wumman q&rabar;th quath þis maide &punctelev; of
hire maidenhod beo ido·/
Fo&rrot; no dede þat men deth þe bodie &punctelev; bote jre h&combtildevert;te herte beo ⁁ þerto·⁁ con&slong;ente"Consent" is added in the same later hand as the solidus marks.
Fo&rrot; þe mo&rrot;e þat mi bodi aȝein mi wille &punctelev; here defouled is·
Þe cle&combmacr;no&rrot;e clennore is mi ma&ydot;⧶
denhod &punctelev; and þe mo&rrot;e mi mede iswi&slong; iwis ·The manuscript reads "iswis", possibly meaning "is wis"; however, some diagonal markings through the "i" and the "s" may indicate that they were marked for deletion, and Horstmann thus interprets the intended word as "iwis". However, the diagonals lines bear a close resemblance to the stroke and ink colour of the later hand's solidus marks, so this deletion may well belong to that hand. In this case, the later reader likely believed that the word should be read as "wis".

And eu&combtildevert;e euere lai þis Maide maide &slong;tille &punctelev; hu&ydot; ne miȝhten
hire ene&slong; waweThe page appears to be ruled for two columns of 52 lines each with the last seven lines faded, especially in the first column. In particular, the ruling at the 46th line is less visible. This is precisely the point whre the scribe began the second column. After writing the 46th line in column 2, he wrote seven lines in column 1 before resuming in column 2 to the end of the text. Insertion marks touched in red located in each column indicate where the text in column 2 continues in column 1, and a line is drawn from the end of column 1 to the point in column 2 where the text resumes. It does not appear that extra ruling was added after the scribe had begun writing, so it is more likely that he assumed that there would be 45 lines per page (encouraged perhaps by the faded ruling) and began column 2 before realising that the remaining text would not fit on the single page. A curiously unmotivated space is left at the beginning of the final line. The page itself is rather worn, especially in column 2 and at the bottom. However, most of the text is clear, and only a few extraordinary words are noted as unclear in the markup.

þe is holi churche &punctelev; ib&rrot;ouȝt in guod pes·
Fo&rrot; hire tweie wiþerwine&slong; &punctelev; þat habbez
ibeo &slong;o ȝare·
Riȝht nouþe beoth to nauȝt
ib&rrot;ouȝt &punctelev; ȝe þo&rrot;ue habbe of heom no kare·
Fo&rrot; þe luþere dioclician Dioclician &punctelev; þat &slong;o muche harm
hath ido·
he is ipult out of hi&slong; k&ydot;nedom &punctelev;
he ne cometh nonmo&rrot;e þarto·
And al
&slong;o Maximian &punctelev; þat &slong;o luþur hath ibeo·
Riȝth nouþe he deide in luþur deth &punctelev; ȝe
&slong;chulle him nonmo&rrot;e i&slong;eo·
So þat þe luþ&combtildevert;e luþere
wiþerwine&slong; &punctelev; þat aȝein holie churche were·
Out of heo&rrot;e miȝhte beoth ib&rrot;ouȝt &punctelev; ne hab
be ȝe none fere·
¶ Þus glade t&ydot;þingue
ich eov b&rrot;ingue &punctelev; þei hu&ydot; feo&rrot; heonne beo·
Ihered beo god God þat ich mo&slong;te &punctelev; þis dai aliue
iseo·
Ichulle biteche ou ih&comcurl; Ihesu
c&combtildevert;&slong;t Crist &punctelev; fo&rrot; fram
eov ich mot wende·
B&rrot;inguth me o&rrot;e louer
de&slong; flech&slong; and is blod &punctelev; fo&rrot; þat schal beo mi&ydot;
ende·The metamarks are an encoding challenge because they occur at a line break in the middle of a word (not to mention in two different columns). I have chosen to encode them as marginal additions at the end of the verse line so that the parts of the word can be merged in the critical view, but there is no way that this encoding will render anything like the mise-en-page.
¶ Þe p&rrot;eo&slong;te&slong; wenden fo&rrot;th anon
and folk þat þ&combtildevert;e þere &slong;tod&punctelev;
And fetten to þi&slong; ho
lie maide &punctelev; gode&slong; Godes
flchs flechs and i&slong; blod·
Þo heo
it hadde underfongue &punctelev; and hire riȝhte&slong; al
&slong;o&punctelev;
And þe o&rrot;e&slong;one&slong; weren alle i&slong;eid &punctelev;
þat bifullen þerto·
Mid þe la&slong;te
word heo ȝaf
þene go&slong;t &punctelev; a&slong;e hu&ydot; amen &slong;eide·

þare weren redie Inowe inowe &punctelev; hire &slong;oule to he
uene lede·

lucie Lucie
